{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox video game | title = Mimpi | image= Mimpi video game cover.jpg | developer = [[Dreadlocks Ltd|Silicon Jelly]] | publisher = Crescent Moon Games | modes = [[Single-player]] | director = Jaroslav Stehlík | producer = Tomáš Klenha | designer = Matěj Moravec | writer = Martin Vaňo{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BE3Mt5So-k0 |title=Martin Vaňo: Mimpi – case study vývoje mobilní hry pro Android v Unity 3D – DevFest Praha 2013 |publisher=YouTube |date=November 27, 2013 |accessdate=February 24, 2014}} | composer = | engine = [[Unity (game engine)|Unity]] | platforms = [[Windows]]
[[Android (operating system)|Android]]
[[iOS]]
[[OS X]] | released = '''iOS:'''
October 8, 2013
'''OSX:'''
December 12, 2013
'''Android:'''
December 19, 2013
'''Microsoft Windows:'''
20 January 2015 | genre = [[Adventure game]]
[[Puzzle video game]]
[[Platform game]] }} '''Mimpi''' is a video game developed by Czech company [[Silicon Jelly]]. It is a mix of an [[Adventure game|adventure]] [[Puzzle video game|puzzle]] and a [[platform game]]. The Sequel [[Mimpi Dreams]] was released in 2015.http://ahoooj.circusatos.com/presskit/index.php?l=cs ==Development== The game was announced in January 2013. The development started approximately in October 2012. Developers decided to fund the game on Indiegogo. The game was placed there in February but until March 4, it gained just 112 USD of 10,000 goal. Developers decided to finish the game anyway. The original release date was scheduled for March 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/mimpi-puzzle-platformer-adventure |title=Mimpi: puzzle platformer adventure |publisher=Indiegogo |date= |accessdate=February 24, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://games.tiscali.cz/oznameni/ceska-puzzle-plosinovka-mimpi-vas-zve-do-kouzleneho-sveta-61867 |title=Česká puzzle plošinovka Mimpi vás zve do kouzleného světa – GAMES.cz |publisher=Games.tiscali.cz |date=January 24, 2013 |accessdate=February 24, 2014}} The most of the game was developed by designer Matěj Moravec. Programmers started their work when he finished first four levels. The music was done by company [[Sype Studios]]. In the course of development the game went through many changes. For example, it was longer and easier than planned.{{cite web|url=http://www.pocketgamer.biz/r/PG.Biz/Mimpi/feature.asp?c=55235 |title=Every dog has its day: The making of Mimpi | feature | Mimpi |publisher=PocketGamer.biz |date=November 13, 2013 |accessdate=February 24, 2014}} The game was finished in October and developers found a publisher in [[Crescent Moon Games]]. IOS version was released on October 8. It was followed by OS X version on December 12. On December 19, a version for [[Android (operating system)|Android]] was released. The game was also Greenlighted for release on Steam. The Windows version was released on 20 January 2015.{{cite web|author=Eric Ford |url=http://toucharcade.com/2013/10/07/hands-on-with-mimpi-gorgeous-puzzle-platforming/ |title=Hands-On with 'Mimpi' – Gorgeous Puzzle Platforming |publisher=Touch Arcade |date=December 6, 2013 |accessdate=February 24, 2014}} ==Gameplay== [[File:Mimpi Screenshot.jpg|250px|thumbnail|left|The game combines Platform and Adventure game. The Player controls Mimpi but also can interact with Environment similarly to [[Point and click]] [[Adventure game]]]] Mimpi is played as a sidescrolling platformer. The player is controlling a dog Mimpi with directional arrows. Player can also interact with surroundings by tapping, swiping, and dragging on it. There is plenty of puzzles that player has to get through. The game is set in 8 different worlds that differs not only by visuals but also by gameplay. In a sea level for example your character is in a bubble and has to avoid touching anything. In the course of game you can find bones. They are used to unlock various illustrations.{{cite web|url=http://applenapps.com/review/mimpi-exploring-a-strange-new-world |title=Mimpi Review – Exploring A Strange New World|publisher=Applenapps.com |date=October 18, 2013 |accessdate=February 24, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://arcadesushi.com/mimpi-review/ |title=Mimpi Review |publisher=Arcadesushi.com |date=October 17, 2013 |accessdate=February 24, 2014}} ==Plot== The story is told by animations without written or voiced dialogues.{{cite web|url=http://www.cultofmac.com/251548/mimpi-is-a-little-dog-on-a-huge-adventure-review/ |title=Mimpi Is A Little Dog on a Huge Adventure [Review |publisher=Cult of Mac |date=October 29, 2013 |accessdate=February 24, 2014}} The game follows story of a little dog Mimpi whose owner disappears when he enjoys his nap during a day. He sets up to find him. He meets strange creatures on his way and some of them are hostile. He gets through multiple environments and overcome multiple dangers. In the end he finds out that his real task is not to find his master but to help himself. When he went for a walk with his master they met some woman and his master didn't pay any attention. Mimpi ate a Chocolate [[Bunny]]. Because of it Mimpi got fever and everything happening is just a toxical [[psychosis]]. In the end Mimpi gets to his own stomach and defeats the Bunny. Mimpi then wakes up on his master's lap. ==Spin-off titles== Silicon Jelly along with publisher Crescent Moon Games released in November 2013 three spin-off titles. '''Mimpi Volleyball''', '''Mimpi Signal''' and '''Mimpi Hidden Objects'''. All of them are free.{{cite web |url=http://www.gamemob.com/news/the-loveable-new-dog-mimpi-receives-three-new-titles/ |title=The Loveable New Dog 'Mimpi' Receives Three New Titles |publisher=Game Mob |date= |accessdate=February 24, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140225220211/http://www.gamemob.com/news/the-loveable-new-dog-mimpi-receives-three-new-titles/ |archivedate=February 25, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} ''Mimpi Hidden Objects'' is a hidden objects game. Player there goes through portraits of scenes that depict the world of Mimpi. There he has to search object that are randomly generated. There are seven scenes known from the original game.{{cite web|url=http://appadvice.com/review/hiddengem-mimpi-hidden-objects |title=Mimpi's Dreaming Again And Needs To Find Items in Mimpi Hidden Objects |publisher=AppAdvice |date=November 13, 2013 |accessdate=February 24, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://toucharcade.com/games/mimpi-hidden-objects |title=Mimpi Hidden Objects Review and Discussion |publisher=Touch Arcade |date=November 8, 2013 |accessdate=February 24, 2014}} In ''Mimpi Volleyball'' player play a volleyball against creatures featured in original game. Every match is set in an environment from the original game. The game features 7 levels, 8 creatures to play against, 7 balls and 7 costumes.{{cite web|url=http://toucharcade.com/games/mimpi-volleyball |title=Mimpi Volleyball Review and Discussion |publisher=Touch Arcade |date=November 12, 2013 |accessdate=February 24, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://appadvice.com/review/hiddengem-mimpi-volleyball |title=Mimpi Gets Bouncy in Mimpi Volleyball |publisher=AppAdvice |date= |accessdate=February 24, 2014}} The last spin-off is ''Mimpi Signal''. Player has to find the right wave by using three different controls to manipulate wavelength, speed or amplitude of the wave{{cite web|url=http://toucharcade.com/games/mimpi-signal |title=Mimpi Signal Review and Discussion |publisher=Touch Arcade |date=November 15, 2013 |accessdate=February 24, 2014}} ==Reception== Mimpi received generally positive reviews from critics upon its release. It was praised for its visuals gameplay and music. On the other hand, it was criticised for its controls and difficulty of some puzzles.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/ios/mimpi-2013 |title=Mimpi (2013) for iPhone/iPad Reviews |publisher=Metacritic |date=October 8, 2013 |accessdate=February 24, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerankings.com/iphone/735935-mimpi-2013/index.html |title=Mimpi (2013) for iOS (iPhone/iPad) |publisher=GameRankings |date=October 8, 2013 |accessdate=February 24, 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://mimpi-game.com/ Official site] *[http://www.sypestudios.com/ Official site of Sype Studios] [[Category:2013 video games]] [[Category:Adventure games]] [[Category:Platform games]] [[Category:Puzzle video games]] [[Category:Indie video games]] [[Category:Steam Greenlight games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Android (operating system) games]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:MacOS games]] [[Category:Unity (game engine) games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Indiegogo projects]] [[Category:Crowdfunded video games]] [[Category:GameStick Games]]

page.title: National Prize of Art of Chile

revision.comment: added link
revision.text:
{{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} The '''National Prize of Art''' of [[Chile]], was created on November 9, 1942. It was awarded yearly since 1944 and alternated the mention among [[Painting]] or [[Sculpture]], [[Music]] and [[Theatre]]. In 1992, it was replaced by the [[National Prize of Chile|National Prizes]] of Plastic Arts, Musical Arts and Arts of the Representation and Audiovisual, respectively.
List of prizewinners with the National Prize of Art:
* 1944 - Pablo Burchard Eggeling - Painting * 1945 - [[Pedro Humberto Allende]] - Music * 1946 - Alejandro Flores Pinaud - Theatre * 1947 - Pedro Reszka Moreau - Painting * 1948 - Enrique Soro Barriga - Music * 1949 - Rafael Frontaura de la Fuente - Theatre * 1950 - [[Camilo Mori|Camilo Mori Serrano]] - Painting * 1951 - Domingo Santa Cruz Wilson - Music * 1952 - Pedro de la Barra - Theatre * 1953 - José Perotti Ronzoni - Sculpture * 1954 - Próspero Bisquertt Prado - Music * 1955 - Américo Vargas Vergara - Theatre * 1956 - José Caracci Vignati - Painting * 1957 - [[Alfonso Leng]] - Music * 1958 - Jorge Quevedo Troncoso - Theatre * 1959 - Benito Rebolledo Correa - Painting * 1960 - Acario Cotapos Baeza - Music * 1961 - José Rojas Ibarra - Theatre * 1962 - Not awarded * 1963 - Not awarded * 1964 - Samuel Román Rojas - Sculpture * 1965 - Carlos Isamitt Alarcón - Music * 1966 - Pedro Sienna - Theatre * 1967 - Laureano Ladrón de Guevara - Painting * 1968 - Alfonso Letelier - Music * 1969 - [[Ana González Olea|Ana González]] - Theatre * 1970 - Marta Colvin - Sculpture * 1971 - [[Gustavo Becerra-Schmidt]] - Music * 1972 - Agustín Siré Sinobas - Music * 1973 - Not awarded * 1974 - [[Ana Cortés]] - Painting * 1975 - Not awarded * 1976 - Jorge Urrutia Blondel - Music * 1977 - Not awarded * 1978 - Pedro Mortheiru Salgado - Theatre * 1979 - Carlos Pedraza Olguín - Painting * 1980 - Víctor Tevah Tellias - Music * 1981 - Fernando Debesa Marín - Theatre * 1982 - [[Mario Carreño Morales]] - Painting * 1983 - [[Claudio Arrau]] - Music * 1984 - Ernest Uthoff Biefand - Ballet * 1985 - Israel Roa Villagra - Painting * 1986 - Federico Heinlein - Music * 1988 - Silvia Piñeiro Rodríguez - Theatre * 1990 - [[Roberto Matta]] - Painting * 1992 - [[Juan Orrego-Salas]] - Music
{{DEFAULTSORT:National Prize Of Art Of Chile}} [[Category:Awards established in 1942]] [[Category:Chilean art]] [[Category:Chilean music]] [[Category:Theatre in Chile]] [[Category:1942 establishments in Chile]]
{{Chile-stub}}

revision.comment: /* "Death" */ excess comma
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{essay|date=November 2013}} {{tone|date=November 2013}} }}
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox comic strip |title=Opus |image=[[File:Opus strip.jpg]] |caption= [[Opus the Penguin]] |creator=[[Berkeley Breathed]] |current= |status=Discontinued |syndicate=[[The Washington Post Company|Washington Post Writers Group]] |genre=Humor, Politics, Satire |first=November 23, 2003 |last=November 2, 2008 |preceded by=[[Outland (comics)|Outland]] }} '''''Opus''''' was a [[Sunday strip]] drawn by [[Berkeley Breathed]] for a period of five years, 2003 to 2008. It was Breathed's fourth [[comic strip]], following ''[[The Academia Waltz]]'', ''[[Bloom County]]'' and ''[[Outland (comics)|Outland]]''.
Set in Bloom County, the strip documented the adventures of Breathed's popular character [[Opus the Penguin]], parodying both pop culture and politics along the way. It was launched with much fanfare on November 23, 2003, and was syndicated by [[The Washington Post Company|Washington Post Writers Group]]. In early October 2008 the author declared he was terminating the strip because of his expectation that the United States is going to face tough times and his desire to depart from his most famous character "on a lighter note".
==Characters==
===Opus=== '''[[Opus the Penguin|Opus]]''' is the title character and protagonist of the strip. Though he returned to [[Antarctica]] at the end of ''Outland'', Opus traveled back home to Bloom County, only to find that time has changed everything and everyone he once held dear. His employment usually depended on the week's joke – since ''Opus'' began, he has so far been a political operative, a garbageman, and a newspaper [[ombudsman]] – but he was most often depicted as a syndicated cartoonist.
While his mother, maiden name Bougm,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gocomics.com/bloomcounty/1989/03/12|title=Bloom County by Berkeley Breathed, March 12, 1989 Via @GoComics|last=Breathed|first=Berkeley|website=GoComics|access-date=2016-12-27}}</ref> was no longer "long-lost," she was not all he had imagined her to be after a decades-long search, and he was frequently seeking the comfort of an ideal mother-figure.
In a 2003 interview with ''[[The A.V. Club]]'', Breathed revealed that "Opus was named after a [[Kansas (band)|Kansas]] song." (The band's 1976 album ''[[Leftoverture]]'' includes the song "Opus Insert" and a suite called "Magnum Opus".) He also added, "If you're too young to know who Kansas was, to hell with you."<ref name=autogenerated3>[http://www.avclub.com/content/node/22539/print/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071008174000/http://www.avclub.com/content/node/22539/print/ |date=October 8, 2007 }}</ref>
===Regular characters=== * '''[[Bill the Cat]]''' – the first of Opus' old friends to re-emerge (just months into the strip), Bill seemed to be the only one completely unchanged by time. Still in a state of [[catatonia]], he was occasionally tapped to run for political office but most often seen relaxing by Opus' side. He did not appear in many strips through the summer and fall of 2008, though. * '''[[Steve Dallas]]''' – Steve was reintroduced little more than a year in, making him the only character to have appeared in a major role in all four of Breathed's comic strips. Steve, who had come out as gay at the end of ''Outland'', was back to his former [[chauvinism|chauvinistic]] ways, apparently as a result of so-called "reparative therapy" (i.e., [[conversion therapy]]). Steve's lack of ability to charm women, however, remained. He had aged quite noticeably and appeared to be in his mid 50s, with graying temples and a receding hairline, but still retained his trademark sunglasses. * '''Pickles''' – A little girl with a little bit of "snarky energy" (she first appeared as a self-proclaimed [[Viking]] princess), Pickles immediately began tagging along with Opus and Bill. She appeared much less frequently towards the end of the strip's run. * '''Auggie Dallas''' – Steve's long lost son, reunited with his father after many years. He had nothing but admiration for Steve, even though Steve was sometimes reluctant to act like a father figure. His name may be a reference to [[Augie Doggie]]. * '''[[Michael Binkley]]''' – A longtime friend of Opus who began appearing in the strip after a somewhat unexplained twelve-year absence (see [[#Absent characters|below]]). He appeared as he did in Bloom County, inexplicably not aging as Steve Dallas had.
===Other characters=== * '''[[Minor characters in Bloom County#Senator Bedfellow|Senator Bedfellow]]''' – Though previously convicted on corruption charges, Bedfellow returned later on, still usually drunk and plagued by reporters. * '''Editor of the ''Bloom Picayune''''' – Usually Opus' boss, the ''Picayune'''s editor was depicted as hyper-stressed and suicidal, though somewhat older than he was in ''Bloom County''. * '''[[Oliver Wendell Jones]]''' – For some reason, Oliver was shown, like Binkley, to be the same age as he had been in ''Bloom County'' and ''Outland''. He reappeared on August 5, 2007. * '''[[Lola Granola]]''' – Opus' one-time fiancée (back in the days of ''Bloom County''), Lola reappeared on August 12, 2007 as Steve's girlfriend. * '''[[Berkeley Breathed]]''' – On November 25, 2007, the cartoonist appeared as himself (using a likeness of [[Sean Connery]] as [[James Bond]] instead of drawing his own face) and "announced" that [[Jim Davis (cartoonist)|Jim Davis's]] character [[Garfield]] is gay in a parody of author [[J. K. Rowling]]'s ex post facto [[outing]] of the [[Harry Potter]] character [[Albus Dumbledore]]. The strip ended with Breathed calling Rowling a "lily-livered literary chicken".<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.salon.com/comics/opus/2007/11/25/opus/index.html/ |title=Opus |publisher=Salon.com |date=2007-11-25 |accessdate=2015-05-29}}</ref>
===Absent characters=== Early on in the strip, it was revealed that Michael Binkley had fled Bloom County to become a teenage [[Tibet]]an [[eunuch]] after a disastrous first kiss (this kiss was described to Binkley by his older self from his anxiety closet in [[Bloom County]]). He was not heard from again until June 3, 2007, when he appeared in his child form without explanation.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.salon.com/comics/opus/2007/06/03/opus/ |title=Opus |publisher=Salon.com |date=2007-06-03 |accessdate=2015-05-29}}</ref>
At one point, Opus ponders the whereabouts of his other buddies from the past. Among those that Opus remembers are [[Milo Bloom]], although Milo's whereabouts have not yet been discussed. Additionally, [[Ronald-Ann Smith]], the original protagonist of ''Outland'', has not been referenced at all in the strip.
At an autograph party for an ''Opus'' anthology book, Breathed revealed that the reason many of the original child characters had not returned is because in the years since the end of ''Outland'', the child characters would have aged into teenagers, and Breathed had no interest in reviving the characters in that form.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.platypuscomix.net/otherpeople/nightwithberke.html |title=My Night With Berkeley Breathed |publisher=Platypuscomix.net |accessdate=2015-05-29}}</ref>
=="Death"== On August 31, 2008, "[[God|the Creator]]" ([[Berkeley Breathed]]) spoke to Opus and hinted that the strip will end soon. The next week, Opus was visited by the ghost of [[Elvis]] who told Opus to find a place where he wants to be forever, because he will stay in that one spot after he "dies." e.g., Elvis is condemned to sit on the toilet forever because that's where he happened to be when he died.
Opus tried to fly to a tropical island on September 14, but when he was asked for his passport, he told the ticket clerk that he smuggled himself into the U.S. 30 years ago. He was promptly arrested by airport security while screaming, "[[God save the Queen|God Bless George Bush!]]" Opus was taken to the [[Department of Homeland Security]] and [[waterboarding|waterboarded]]. The guards told him to "start talking, [[Hasan Akbar case|Akbar]]!" Opus complained to "the Creator," saying he couldn't just let the strip end like this. "The Creator" then placed Opus in an [[animal shelter]], and mockingly said, "Happy?" to which Opus replied "NO!!"
The next week, September 26, 2008, saw Opus bemoaning having to spend his eternity in a county animal shelter. At the behest of a fellow inmate, a scruffy dog, Opus soon began sharing his memories of his past and recounts his life through the run of Breathed's strips. Many shots of him in well-known stories from ''Bloom County'' are then shown, including Opus saying "bozo" to a politician on the TV in 1981, misunderstanding a money-grubbing cultist in 1982, sharing a mass dandelion break with other characters in 1983, his role in the rock band ''[[Deathtöngue]]'' in 1984, dreaming romantically of [[Diane Sawyer]] in 1985, and a current joke about [[Sarah Palin]] set in 1986. The strip included a tag at the bottom indicating it would be continued the next week.
At this point, a trio of island-native girls arrive at the shelter; they only have room for one companion to live with them in their paradise.
On October 6, 2008, Breathed announced that the strip would end after November 2 that year,<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/herocomplex/2008/10/berkeley-breath.html |title=Berkeley Breathed says goodbye to Opus: ‘I’m destroying the village to save it’ | Hero Complex – movies, comics, pop culture – Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimesblogs.latimes.com |date=2008-10-06 |accessdate=2015-05-29}}</ref> and even decided to do a contest for people to guess what Opus's fate is on BerkeleyBreathed.com. The winner will have $10,000 donated to the animal shelter of their choosing.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.berkeleybreathed.com/pages/ContestRules.htm |title=Opus Contest |publisher=Berkeleybreathed.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120218074030/http://www.berkeleybreathed.com/pages/ContestRules.htm |archivedate=February 18, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On October 19, 2008, Steve Dallas was shown barging into the Bloom County Animal Shelter's lobby demanding to see Opus, claiming Opus owed him $20. The clerk stationed there informed Steve that Opus had chosen his final eternity and that Steve should do so likewise, and very quickly. The conversation ended with Steve finally realizing he was in a cartoon strip by breaking the fourth wall and asking the clerk who "all those scruffy-looking people [are]" as he looked at the readers, to which the clerk replied, "Probably [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] at this point," since he did this after dropping his towel, standing naked (but with a [[censor bar]] over his groin).
The next week, Steve found the tropical island girls and told them to give back Opus. It was then revealed that Opus had let his doggy companion in the shelter go with the girls, said "goodnight", and returned to the kennel. After seeing a vision of former ''Bloom County'' residents (Milo, Binkley, Oliver, Cutter John, Portnoy, and Bill the Cat) waving goodbye as they rode off into the distance atop Cutter John's wheelchair, Steve walked back to the animal shelter to find nothing but Opus' bow tie and an empty kennel. The final strip showed a glowing light coming from a box inside the kennel. Steve reaches into the box, and smiles at what he sees. The panel showed the address of a link to the Humane Society, which displayed the last panel as part of the $10,000 contest (it would later be printed in '' Berkeley Breathed's Opus: The Complete Library''). The final strip showed Steve opening a copy of ''[[Goodnight Moon]]'' and seeing Opus tucked in bed, sleeping peacefully with a mother rabbit watching over him.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.hsus.org/forms/the_opus_contest.html |title= The Opus $10,000 Paradise Contest |date = 6 November 2008 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081110120144/http://www.hsus.org/forms/the_opus_contest.html | archivedate=November 10, 2008 | accessdate= 22 July 2015 |publisher= Humane Society of the United States}}</ref>
The 2015 revival of the ''[[Bloom County]]'' comic strip reveals that Opus is still alive, only that he has been unconscious the past 25 years and that the events of ''Opus'' and ''Outland'' were all an elaborate [[dream sequence]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/07/13/422545636/bloom-county-2015-berkeley-breathed-revives-comic-strip |title= 'Bloom County 2015': Berkeley Breathed Revives Comic Strip | date = 13 July 2015 | accessdate= 22 July 2015 |publisher=NPR}}</ref>
==Production history== In numerous interviews before launching ''Opus'', Berke Breathed stated his hopes that the strip would help reinvigorate the medium of [[comic strips|newspaper comics]]. He criticized many modern strips, especially ''[[Garfield]]'', for lacking expressive artwork or original humor.<ref name=autogenerated3 /><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Jarnow |first=Jesse |url=http://dir.salon.com/story/ent/feature/2003/11/20/breathed/index.html?pn=2 |title=The penguin is mightier than the sword |publisher=Salon.com |date= |accessdate=September 16, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402034501/http://dir.salon.com/story/ent/feature/2003/11/20/breathed/index.html?pn=2 |archivedate=April 2, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In an interview appearing in the April 2007 issue of ''[[Texas Monthly]]'', Breathed announced that he planned to end the strip by killing off the main character.<ref>[http://www.texasmonthly.com/2007-04-01/bookreviews.php ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205180639/http://www.texasmonthly.com/2007-04-01/bookreviews.php |date=February 5, 2012 }}</ref> On April 2, 2007 the journal ''[[Editor & Publisher]]'' reported on this interview in a story titled "Will Cartoonist Berkeley Breathed Kill Off Opus the Penguin?"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.editorandpublisher.com/eandp/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003566079 |title=Editor & Publisher |publisher=Editorandpublisher.com |date=June 17, 2009 |accessdate=September 16, 2009}}</ref> However, Breathed's editor has reportedly quoted him as stating, "I mentioned Opus' literal death just for talking points on my [book] tour coming up. Not gonna kill him, but it's good for copy."<ref>{{cite web|last=Gardner |first=Alan |url=http://dailycartoonist.com/index.php/2007/04/02/berkeley-breathed-planning-to-end-opus/ |title=Berkeley Breathed planning to end Opus? (UPDATED) » The Daily Cartoonist |publisher=The Daily Cartoonist<! |date=April 2, 2007 |accessdate=September 16, 2009}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=September 2009}} Breathed confirmed that he was joking in an interview with [[Salon.com|Salon]]: "I was kidding about killing Opus, by the way. I'd like to walk the streets free from fears of spontaneous [[garrot]]ing."<ref name=autogenerated1>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.salon.com/books/feature/2007/06/03/breathed/ |title=Opus day! |publisher=Salon.com |date=June 3, 2007 |accessdate=September 16, 2009}}</ref>
In August 2008, the strip began a sequence playing off the 2007 interview, as "the Creator" of the strip informed Opus that "the end is near." The strip ended on Sunday, November 2, 2008, with Opus snugly in bed at the conclusion of ''[[Goodnight Moon]]''.
==Artwork and availability== The original syndication contract for ''Opus'' stipulated that the strip occupy an entire half of a newspaper page. According to [[Washington Post Company|The Washington Post Writers Group]], this was to provide ''"space for Breathed to offer richness and depth, similar to the breathtaking imagery in his popular children's books."''<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.postwritersgroup.com/opus.htm |title=Washington Post | News Service & Syndicate |publisher=Postwritersgroup.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-29}}</ref> While this style can appear hand-painted or [[airbrushing|airbrushed]], it is actually rendered by Breathed on a computer using [[Adobe Photoshop]]. The half-page requirement was subsequently lifted, and the strip scaled down by most newspapers. Its original illustration style has also been largely abandoned in favor of a more hand-drawn look, much like that of Breathed's previous strip, ''Outland''.
Initially, in an effort to help boost physical newspaper sales, the strip was barred from appearing [[online]]; however, in 2005, that too changed and ''Opus'' became officially available on the [[world wide web|web]].<ref>[http://www.comics.com/wash/opus/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070507074857/http://www.comics.com/wash/opus/ |date=May 7, 2007 }}</ref>
On August 26, 2007, the strip featured Lola Granola wearing a headscarf, explaining that she was now a "radical [[Islamist]]." The cartoon was not printed by the ''[[Washington Post]]'' and many other papers.<ref>{{Cite journal|author=Joan Walsh |url=http://www.salon.com/opinion/walsh/media/2007/08/26/opus/index.html |title=Joan Walsh – Political Commentary and News |publisher=Salon |date=August 26, 2007 |accessdate=September 16, 2009}}</ref> The following week's strip was also censored.<ref>{{Cite journal|author=Joan Walsh |url=http://www.salon.com/opinion/walsh/media/2007/09/02/opus/ |title=Joan Walsh – Political Commentary and News |publisher=Salon |date=September 2, 2007 |accessdate=September 16, 2009}}</ref> Both strips were replaced by more innocuous strips in the printed versions, but the 'objectionable' strips relating to Lola's religious beliefs were offered in a variety of Internet comics sites, including Breathed's homepage and the "My Comics Page" site. This site now requires a paid "pro" registration for access to the censored strips, but free access to the censored strips is still available online.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.salon.com/comics/opus/2007/08/26/opus/index.html |title=Opus |publisher=Salon.com |date=2007-08-26 |accessdate=2015-05-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.salon.com/comics/opus/2007/09/02/opus/index.html |title=Opus |publisher=Salon.com |date=2007-09-02 |accessdate=2015-05-29}}</ref>
==The movie== In August 2006 [[The Weinstein Company]] revealed in a [[press release]] for an animated version of ''[[The Nutty Professor]]'' that it had a "[[Computer-generated imagery|CG-animated project]]" called "Opus" "in the works".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_pwwi/is_200608/ai_n16632590 | work=Market Wire | title=Mainframe Entertainment and The Weinstein Company Team Up for CG Animated "The Nutty Professor" | year=2006}}</ref> Numerous online movie databases, including ''[[The New York Times]]'', have entries for the movie, titled ''Opus: The Last Christmas'', and give a release date of December 19, 2008.<ref>{{cite news|last=Cieply |first=Michael |url=http://movies2.nytimes.com/gst/movies/movie.html?v_id=358566 |title=Opus: The Last Christmas – Trailer – Cast – Showtimes – New York Times |publisher=Movies2.nytimes.com |date=April 12, 2007 |accessdate=September 16, 2009}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/films.php?id=15965 |title=Opus: The Last Christmas – ComingSoon.net Film Database |publisher=Comingsoon.net |date= |accessdate=September 16, 2009}}</ref> Some of these sites name Berkeley Breathed as the director,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.moviecentre.net/upcomingmovies/preview/movie_id_1837.htm |title=Opus: The Last Christmas | Preview | Reviews | Trailers | Moviecentre.net |publisher=Moviecentre.net<! |date= |accessdate=September 16, 2009| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080211111539/http://www.moviecentre.net/upcomingmovies/preview/movie_id_1837.htm| archivedate = February 11, 2008}}</ref> while others list Tim Bjorklund and Paul Taylor.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> Initially, [[Miramax Films]] was reported to have obtained the movie rights to the series,<ref>[http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2008/OPUS.php ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061110070435/http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2008/OPUS.php |date=November 10, 2006 }}</ref> but the project migrated to [[The Weinstein Company]] with the departure of the Weinstein brothers from [[Disney]] and [[Miramax]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/film/4392881.stm |title=Weinsteins step down from Miramax |publisher=BBC News |date=March 31, 2005 |accessdate=September 16, 2009}}</ref>
However, on May 8, 2007, during an interview<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wamu.org/programs/dr/07/05/08.php |title=WAMU 88.5 FM American University Radio – The Diane Rehm Show for Tuesday May 8, 2007 |publisher=Wamu.org |date=May 8, 2007 |accessdate=September 16, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090924165954/http://wamu.org/programs/dr/07/05/08.php |archivedate=September 24, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> by [[NPR]] radio host [[Diane Rehm]], Mr. Breathed responded to an e-mail question regarding the existence of ''Opus: The Last Christmas'' by saying, {{quote|Uh, the better question is, 'Is there an Opus movie going to come out?' and the answer is 'no.' And, now I can say it's all for the better. Uh, the Weinstein brothers at Miramax tried for five years to develop an Opus movie, their first animated film, and it was, let me just say, it probably wasn't destined to be, as ... as it probably shouldn't. And the problem with developing these kinds of movies and films is that inevitably they discover that a property as idiosyncratic as a comic strip doesn't translate well unless you have the confidence of bringing the creator in and factoring him into the creation of the movie. They never, never do that. Yeah, um, they just don't trust us. So without that control there probably shouldn't be an Opus movie.}} In a June 2007 interview with [[Salon.com]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> Breathed confirmed that the [[Miramax]] feature was "dead", but left the door open for an [[independent film|independently produced]] Opus film: {{quote|There'll only be a movie if I'm writing it, which will probably keep him off the big expensive screen ... probably just as well.}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.berkeleybreathed.com Berkeley Breathed official site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050721000106/http://www.uclick.com/client/wpc/wpopu/ ''Opus'' archive] at washingtonpost.com * [http://www.websnark.com/archives/2007/08/ackphhlpt.html Eric: Ack-phhlpt.] – ''[[Websnark]]''

page.title: Ori and the Will of the Wisps

revision.comment: /* Development */CE
revision.text:
{{Infobox video game | title = Ori and the Will of the Wisps | image = Ori and the Will of the Wisps.jpg | developer = [[Moon Studios]] | publisher = [[Microsoft Studios]] | engine = [[Unity (game engine)|Unity]] | platforms = {{Unbulleted list|[[Microsoft Windows]]|[[Xbox One]]}} | released = 2019 | genre = [[Platform game#Platform-adventure games|Platform-adventure]], [[Metroidvania]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] | composer = Gareth Coker }} '''''Ori and the Will of the Wisps''''' is an upcoming [[Platform game#Platform-adventure games|platform-adventure]] [[Metroidvania]] [[video game]] developed by [[Moon Studios]] and published by [[Microsoft Studios]] for [[Microsoft Windows]] and [[Xbox One]]. It is a sequel to the 2015 title ''[[Ori and the Blind Forest]]'' and was announced during [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2017]].
The game is planned to be a [[Ultra-high-definition television|4K UHD]], [[List of Xbox One X Enhanced games|Xbox One X Enhanced]] and [[Xbox Live|Xbox Play Anywhere]] title.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gematsu.com/2017/06/ori-will-wisps-announced-xbox-one-windows-10|title=Ori and the Will of the Wisps announced for Xbox One|last=|first=|date=2017-06-11|work=Gematsu|access-date=2017-08-26|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Gameplay== Players assume control of Ori, a white guardian spirit. To progress in the game, players are tasked to move between platforms and solve puzzles. Similarly to ''[[Ori and the Blind Forest|The Blind Forest]]'', ''Will of the Wisps'' is expected to feature a system called "soul links", which allows players to save at will, and an upgrade system that gives players the ability to strengthen Ori's skills. The game world unfolds to the player in the fashion of a [[Metroidvania]], with new abilities allowing the player to access previously inaccessible areas. Some of the foundational gameplay elements were inspired by the ''[[Rayman]]'' and ''[[Metroid]]'' franchises.
The game story is centered on a new adventure to discover the world beyond the forest of Nibel, uncover the truths of the lost ones, and unearth Ori's true destiny.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.xbox.com/en-US/games/ori-will-of-the-wisps|title=Ori and the Will of the Wisps for Xbox One and Windows 10|last=|first=|date=|website=Xbox.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-26}}</ref>
== Development == The game was announced at [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2017]] (E3) on 11 June 2017 with a teaser trailer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/6/11/15779186/ori-and-the-will-of-the-wisps-new-sequel-blind-forest-xbox-e3|title=Ori and the Will of the Wisps is the new sequel to the beautiful Ori and the Blind Forest|last=Gartenberg|first=Chaim|date=2017-06-11|website=The Verge|access-date=2017-06-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2017/06/12/ori-and-the-will-of-the-wisps-announced-about-sad-owls/|title=Ori and the Will of the Wisps announced, about sad owls|last=Smith|first=Graham|date=2017-06-12|website=Rock, Paper, Shotgun|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://kotaku.com/microsoft-announces-ori-and-the-will-of-the-wisps-1796000967|title=Microsoft Announces Ori And The Will Of The Wisps|last=Grayson|first=Nathan|date=2017-06-11|work=Kotaku|access-date=2017-08-21|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref> The trailer depicts new lands, and Ori with a young owl. Gareth Coker, who performed during the E3 unveiling,<ref>Track written by Gareth Coker for the E3 2017 reveal can be listened to at either [https://garethcoker.bandcamp.com/track/ori-and-the-will-of-the-wisps-teaser-music Bandcamp] or [https://soundcloud.com/garethcoker/ori-and-the-will-of-the-wisps-e3-2017-trailer Soundcloud].</ref> was similarly announced to return to compose the score.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.vgmonline.net/gareth-coker-announced-ori-will-of-wisps/|title=Gareth Coker announced to score Ori and the Will of the Wisps|date=2017-06-12|work=VGMO -Video Game Music Online-|access-date=2017-08-25|language=en-US}}</ref> Moon Studios lead developers [[Gennadiy Korol]] and [[Thomas Mahler]] commented that the team is "crazy iterative" when developing the game. For example, the E3 2017 teaser trailer went through 2,000 iterations during polishing.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.trueachievements.com/n28650/ori-and-the-will-of-the-wisps-developer-interview|title=Ori and the Will of the Wisps Developer Interview|last=|first=|date=2017-06-15|work=TrueAchievements|access-date=2017-06-17|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> As for setting the standard and vision of the game, Mahler said that "''Will of the Wisps'' should be to ''Blind Forest'' what ''[[Super Mario Bros. 3]]'' was to the original ''[[Super Mario Bros.]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.neogaf.com/forum/showthread.php?t=1389585&page=5|title=Ori and the Will of the Wisps E3 trailer, Page 5, Post #225|last=|first=|date=2017-06-12|website=NeoGAF|language=en|citeseerx=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-25|quote=Trust us a little :) I wouldn't worry too much. Will of the Wisps isn't just a visual upgrade, far from it. The idea is that Will of the Wisps should be to Blind Forest what Super Mario Bros 3 was to the original Super Mario Bros :)}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://daily.bandcamp.com/2017/08/21/gareth-coker-interview/|title=Gareth Coker Is A Name You Should Know In Video Game Music|last=Editorial|date=2017-08-21|website=Bandcamp Daily|access-date=2017-08-25}}</ref>
On 7 August 2017, ''[[AM2R]]'' developer Milton Guasti was announced to have joined the Ori team as a level designer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.usgamer.net/articles/am2r-creator-speechless-when-offered-ori-and-the-will-of-the-wisps-job|title=AM2R Creator "Speechless" When Offered Ori and the Will of the Wisps Job|last=Kim|first=Matt|date=2017-08-09|website=USgamer|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-08-21}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2017/08/07/another-metroid-2-remake-developer-is-designing-levels-for-ori-and-the-will-of-the-wisps/|title=Another Metroid 2 Remake developer is designing levels for Ori and the Will of the Wisps|date=2017-08-07|website=VentureBeat|access-date=2017-08-21}}</ref> Moon Studios released a video in October 2017 that showcased the design program used to develop cinematics of the game. The program reportedly allowed animators to make changes while in progress and thus allows for a more flexible and streamlined process.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://gamerant.com/ori-will-of-the-wisps-cinematic/|title=Ori and the Will of the Wisps Video Shows Cinematic Tool|date=2017-10-15|work=Game Rant|access-date=2017-11-02|language=en-US}}</ref>
A second trailer was revealed at [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2018]] on June 10 2018, depicting new NPCs, bosses, movement and combat abilities, and revealing its 2019 release date.<ref>{{Citation|last=Xbox|title=Ori and the Will of the Wisps - E3 2018 - Gameplay Trailer|date=2018-06-10|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kd0zbNw1VOg|accessdate=2018-06-10}}</ref>
==Release== ''Ori and the Will of the Wisps'' is scheduled to be released in 2019.
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == *[http://www.orithegame.com/#!moon-3/ Official website] *[http://www.xbox.com/en-US/games/ori-will-of-the-wisps Official Xbox website for the game] {{Authority control}}{{Portal bar|Video games}}

{{Infobox person | name = Paul Sills | image = | image_size = | caption = | alt = | birth_name = Paul Silverberg | birth_date = {{birth date|1927|11|18|df=y|}} | birth_place = [[Chicago, Illinois]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2008|6|2|1927|11|18|df=y|}} | death_place = [[Baileys Harbor, Wisconsin]] | death_cause = Pneumonia | nationality = American | citizenship = United States | education = B.A. from the University of Chicago | alma_mater = [[University of Chicago]] | home_town = Chicago, Illinois | residence = Baileys Harbor, Wisconsin,
Chicago, Illinois | boards = [[The Second City]],
Founded or co-founded:
Playwrights Theater Club,
Compass Players,
The Second City,
Game Theater,
Story Theater,
Sills & Co.,
Paul Sills' Wisconsin Theater Game Center,
The Parents School | influenced = | influences = | notable_works = | known_for = Founding Director of The Second City; creator of Story Theater | occupation = Director, teacher | years_active = | spouse = Dorothea Horton (? – ?; divorced),
[[Barbara Harris (actress)|Barbara Harris]] (1955 – 1958; divorced),
Carol Sills (? – 2008; his death) | children = 1 son,
4 daughters | family = 4 grandchildren,
5 great-grandchildren | parents = [[Viola Spolin]] and Wilmer Silverberg | signature = | awards = Theater Hall of Fame | website = [http://www.paulsills.com paulsills.com] | footnotes = }} '''Paul Silverberg''' (November 18, 1927 – June 2, 2008), better known as '''Paul Sills''', was an American director and [[improvisation]] teacher, and the original director of [[Chicago]]'s [[The Second City]]. ==Life and career== Sills was born Paul Silverberg in Chicago, Illinois, to a family who believed in the teachings of modern-day Judaism. His mother was teacher and writer [[Viola Spolin]], who authored the first book on improvisation techniques, ''Improvisation for the Theater''.{{cite book|title=Improvisation for the Theater Third Edition|author=Viola Spolin|year=1999|ISBN=0-8101-4008-X}} Spolin in turn was the student of play therapy theorist [[Neva Boyd]].Drama as therapy: theatre as living By Phil Jones In 1948, Sills enrolled in the [[University of Chicago]], where he established himself as a director, co-founding Playwright's Theater Club. There, with fellow actors [[Edward Asner]], [[Byrne Piven]] and [[Zohra Lampert]],Coleman, Janet, The Compass. Knopf 1990, pg 16: "Until Paul Sills 'thrust' her onstage...Zohra Lampert ('52) thought, 'I might want to become...a librarian. Not an actor.'" they blended Spolin's improvisational techniques with established theater training. In 1955, Sills and [[David Shepherd (producer)|David Shepherd]] founded the [[Compass Players]], the first [[improvisational theater]] in the United States, where he directed [[Shelley Berman]], [[Mike Nichols]] and [[Elaine May]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ldb77d9WzYsC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Compass+Coleman,+Janet&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjdzYr9jZTXAhUp5IMKHSOuBmoQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=The+Compass+Coleman,+Janet&f=false|title=The Compass: The Improvisational Theatre that Revolutionized American Comedy|first=Janet|last=Coleman|date=1 November 1991|publisher=University of Chicago Press|via=Google Books}} In 1959, Sills, along with partners [[Howard Alk]] and [[Bernie Sahlins]], opened a theatre called [[The Second City]] where revues developed improvisationally were presented under Sills's direction.Coleman, Janet, The Compass, Knopf 1990, pg 255 With early cast members [[Alan Arkin]], [[Barbara Harris (actress)|Barbara Harris]], [[Severn Darden]], Mina Kolb and [[Paul Sand]], success led to New York (a brief run on Broadway and a long one off-Broadway), London and world recognition. {{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} ==Career== Sills left Second City in 1965 to form the Game Theater, where he coached his mother, Viola Spolin's improvisational techniques in performance and audience participation was encouraged. His mother and other community friends were partners. The Parents School was co-founded there, with wife Carol and others, with a children's curriculum based on group art forms and play. It operated for almost two decades. At the Game Theater, he also discovered a new form he called [[Paul Sill's Story Theatre|Story Theater]], which debuted at 1848 N. Wells Street, during the summer of 1968. That building was the original location of the Second City, which had already moved to its new and current location at 1616 N. Wells St. After Sills finished doing Story Theater there, it was torn down.{{cite web|url=http://www.secondcity.com/history/1967/|title=1967 - The Second City|work=secondcity.com}} ''Story Theatre'' went on to play at [[Yale University]], in [[Los Angeles]] and on Broadway,{{cite web|url=http://www.ibdb.com/production.php?id=3091|title=Paul Sills' Story Theatre|website=www.ibdb.com}} remaining the form Sills explored for the rest of his life. His book, ''Paul Sills' Story Theater: Four Shows{{Cite book|title=Story Theater: Four Shows Adapted for the Stage by Paul Sills|last=Sills|first=Paul|publisher=Applause|year=2000|isbn=1557833982|location=New York, N.Y.|pages=}}''. Sills's first two wives were Dorothea Horton and [[Barbara Harris (actress)|Barbara Harris]].{{cn|date=October 2017}} In 2011, he was posthumously inducted into the [[American Theater Hall of Fame]].{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/159061-Tyne-Daly-Ben-Vereen-Ann-Roth-Daniel-Sullivan-and-More-Inducted-Into-Theater-Hall-of-Fame-Jan-30|title=Playbill.com|publisher=}} ==Death== Paul Sills died on June 2, 2008 at the age of 80, at his home in [[Baileys Harbor, Wisconsin]], of complications from [[pneumonia]]. He is survived by his third wife Carol, a son, four daughters, four grandchildren, and five great grandchildren. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://PaulSills.com Paul Sills' Wisconsin Theater Game Center] *[http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5gAxKfFk0g6lJMOX3yC7zZJBEZjbgD91292LG0 "The Second City" founder Paul Sills dies at 80]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{DramaDesk Director}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sills, Paul}} [[Category:1927 births]] [[Category:2008 deaths]] [[Category:American theatre directors]] [[Category:American Theater Hall of Fame inductees]] [[Category:Deaths from pneumonia]] [[Category:Drama teachers]] [[Category:Infectious disease deaths in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Improvisational theatre]] [[Category:Male actors from Chicago]] [[Category:People from Baileys Harbor, Wisconsin]] [[Category:University of Chicago alumni]]

revision.comment: Fixed a typo where a name had crept in?
revision.text:
{{about|the female opera singer|other uses|Prima Donna (disambiguation)}} {{italic title}} [[File:PRIMA DONNA (Ship) (c112-02-14).jpg|thumb|right|
''Prima Donna'' [[Clipper|clipper ship]] card
]] In [[opera]] or [[commedia dell'arte]], a '''prima donna''' ({{IPA-it|ˈpriːma ˈdɔnna|}}; plural: ''prime donne''; [[Italian language|Italian]] for "first lady") is the leading [[female]] singer in the company, the person to whom the prime roles would be given. The prima donna was normally, but not necessarily, a [[soprano]]. The corresponding term for the male lead (almost always a [[tenor]]) is '''primo uomo.'''H. Rosenthal, H. and J. Warrack, ''The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Opera'', 2nd Edition, Oxford University Press, 1979. p. 398. {{ISBN|0-19-311321-X}} ''Prime donne'' often had grand off-stage personalities and were seen as demanding of their colleagues. From its original usage in opera, the term has spread in contemporary usage to refer to anyone behaving in a demanding or temperamental fashion or having an inflated view of oneself and a [[narcissism|narcissistic]] attitude. ==Opera== In 19th-century Italy, the leading woman in an opera or Commedia dell'arte company was known as the ''prima donna'', literally the "first lady". This woman, usually the principal soprano of the company, would typically perform leading roles and generally sang more music than other women in the company. Famous opera prime donne have often caused opera enthusiasts to divide into opposing "clubs" supporting one singer over another. The rivalry between the fans of [[Maria Callas]] and [[Renata Tebaldi]], for example, was one of the most famous, despite the friendship of the two singers.See for example, George Jellinek, [https://books.google.com/books?id=AARY5QG7U3EC&printsec=frontcover#PPA96,M1 ''Callas: Portrait of a Prima Donna''], Dover, 1986, p. 96 and ''passim''. {{ISBN|0486250474}}. The designation ''prima donna assoluta'' (absolute first lady) is occasionally applied to a prima donna of outstanding excellence.''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' (Draft revision 2009). It has also been used to describe the creators of heroic coloratura roles in the first half of the 19th century.Riggs, Geoffrey (2003). [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=GhXggJliLF8C&pg=PA1 ''The Assoluta Voice in Opera, 1797–1847''], p. 1. McFarland. {{ISBN|0786414014}}. ==Personality== At times, these ''prime donne'' (the Italian plural form) were grand with their off-stage personalities and demands on fellow troupe members, musicians, set and wardrobe designers, producers and other staff, but were deferentially tolerated because of their consummate talent and their draw at the box office. From this experience, the term ''prima donna'' has come into common usage in any field denoting someone who behaves in a demanding, often temperamental fashion, revealing an inflated view of themselves, their talent, and their importance.Susan Rutherford, [https://books.google.com/books?id=s1j6Jl2LOfgC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Prima+donna&lr=&sig=A68hBbMrp3tzzAT70dvP8RIoJ2s#PRA1-PA44,M1 ''The Prima Donna and Opera, 1815–1930''], Cambridge University Press, 2006. {{ISBN|0-521-85167-X}}. Due to this association, the contemporary meaning of the word has taken on this negative connotation of a [[vanity|vain]], undisciplined, [[Egotism|egotistical]], obnoxious or temperamental person who finds it difficult to work under direction or as part of a team, but whose contributions are essential to the success of a team.The Oxford Pocket Dictionary of Current English (2009). [http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1O999-primadonna.html "prima donna"]. Encyclopedia.com. 12 Sep. 2010.[[Merriam-Webster]]. [http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/prima+donna "prima donna"]. Merriam-Webster.com. ==See also== *[[Convenienze]] *[[Diva]] *[[Entitlement]] == References == {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== {{wiktionary}} * [[Rupert Christiansen]], ''Prima Donna: A History'', Viking, 1985. {{ISBN|0-670-80482-7}} {{Opera terms}} {{Narcissism}} [[Category:Italian opera terminology]] [[Category:Commedia dell'arte]] [[Category:Female singers]] [[Category:Narcissism]]

{{Infobox video game |title = Rabbids Go Home |image = RabbitsCover2.png |caption = [[PAL region|PAL]] cover art |developer = [[Ubisoft Pictures]]
[[Ubisoft Casablanca]] ([[Nintendo DS]] Version) |publisher = [[Ubisoft]] |director = Jacques Exertier{{cite web |url=http://blogs.nintendolife.com/rabbidsgohome/2009/09/part_1_the_adventure_begins |title=Blog: Part 1 - The Adventure Begins! |author=Jacques Exertier |date=2009-09-09 |publisher=Rabbids Go Home Developer's Blog |accessdate=2010-06-29 }}
Jean-Philippe Caro{{cite web |url=http://blogs.nintendolife.com/rabbidsgohome/2009/10/part_5_inside_the_wii_remote |title=Blog: Part 5 - Inside The Wii Remote |author=Jean-Philippe Caro |date=2009-10-07 |publisher=Rabbids Go Home Developer's Blog |accessdate=2010-06-29 }} |producer = |designer = Christophe Pic{{cite web|url=http://blogs.nintendolife.com/rabbidsgohome/2009/09/part_3_gameplay_loop |title=Blog: Part 3 - Gameplay Loop |author=Christophe Pic |date=2009-09-10 |publisher=Rabbids Go Home Developer's Blog |accessdate=2010-06-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091127093444/http://blogs.nintendolife.com/rabbidsgohome/2009/09/part_3_gameplay_loop |archivedate=November 27, 2009 }} |artist = |writer = |composer = Fanfare Vagabontu |series = ''[[Raving Rabbids]]'' |engine = [[LyN]] |released = '''Nintendo Wii/Nintendo DS'''{{vgrelease|NA|November 1, 2009|}} {{vgrelease|AUS|November 5, 2009}}{{vgrelease|EU|November 6, 2009}}{{vgrelease|JP|November 26, 2009{{cite web|url=http://www.gamespot.com/wii/adventure/rabbidsgohome/similar.html?mode=versions |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' for Wii |publisher=GameSpot |accessdate=December 29, 2009}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/ds/adventure/rabbidsgohome/similar.html?mode=versions |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' for DS |publisher=GameSpot |accessdate=December 29, 2009}}}}'''Microsoft Windows'''
{{vgrelease|[[Russia|RUS]]|August 12, 2010{{cite web |url=http://www.1cmkazan.ru/?cat=newcd&id=3086&s=0 |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' for PC |accessdate=August 2, 2010}}}}{{vgrelease|[[Poland|PL]]|March 30, 2011{{cite web |url=http://www.egmont.pl/pl/czasopisma/nasze_czasopisma/art77.html |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' for PC Poland |accessdate=April 19, 2011}}}} |genre = [[action-adventure game|action adventure]], [[platformer]], [[Puzzle video game|puzzle]] (DS version only) |modes = [[Single-player]], [[Multiplayer game|multiplayer]] |platforms = [[Wii]], [[Nintendo DS]], [[Microsoft Windows]] }} '''''Rabbids Go Home''''' is an [[action-adventure game|action-adventure]] video game developed by [[Ubisoft Pictures]] and published by [[Ubisoft]] for the [[Wii]] and [[Nintendo DS]]. The game was released in North America on November 1, 2009, in Australia on November 5, 2009 and in Europe on November 6, 2009. The modified, shorter version of the game was ported to [[Microsoft Windows]] and released in selected countries (Russia, Germany, Poland). This is also the first game that the Rabbids become allies with the player. ''Rabbids Go Home'' is the fourth installment in the ''[[Raving Rabbids|Rabbids]]'' series of video games and is the first stand-alone title in the series, since Rayman does not appear in the game. The game's plot centers on the efforts of the titular Rabbids to collect as many human objects as they can and create a huge pile high enough to reach the Moon, all the while avoiding the extermination attempts by the "Verminators", who wish to gain back the stuff the Rabbids have stolen. The game received generally favorable reviews from critics, who praised the game's humor, soundtrack and accessible gameplay, though some noted the game's low difficultyhttp://www.metacritic.com/game/wii/rabbids-go-home The reviews for the Nintendo DS version were mixed. The online services for the game were shut down on August 8, 2014.{{cite web|url=https://forums.ubi.com/showthread.php/1241617-Online-Services-Update-Masterlist|title=Online Services Update Masterlist|publisher=[[Ubisoft]]|accessdate=March 12, 2018}} ==Gameplay (Wii version)== The player controls a team of two Rabbids on a rampage pushing a shopping cart.{{cite web |url=http://wii.ign.com/articles/979/979811p1.html |title=Why You'll Love ''Rabbids Go Home'' - Wii feature - at IGN |author=Matt Casamassina |date=May 5, 2009 |publisher=IGN |accessdate=December 29, 2009}} The goal of the game is to go to human places such as malls, hospitals and other such places to collect as much stuff as possible during each level and help the Rabbids build a pile high enough to reach the Moon. In each level, there is enough stuff to grow the pile by 1,000 feet. The minimum requirement for completing a level is to collect the "Xtra Large Stuff" and carry it to the toilet at the end of the level and unlock new items for the Rabbids like figurines, tattoos, tools, accessories and challenges depending on the score.{{cite book |title=Rabbids Go Home instruction booklet |year=2009 |publisher=Ubisoft |page=4 |accessdate=December 29, 2009}} The Xtra Large Stuff is located either in the middle or end of a level. Some Xtra Large items affect the gameplay. For example, a [[jet engine]] will propel the shopping cart to three times its normal speed, while a sickly patient's quarantine bed allows the cart to float and glide. Placed throughout the levels are "Collector Rabbids", with which the player can leave any stuff they have collected up to that point. The [[Health (gaming)|health]] of the Rabbids (described in-game as "ideas") is measured in [[light bulb]]s, which fry out when the Rabbids take damage and get collected to refill. At the start of the game, the Rabbids will have three light bulbs, displayed at the bottom-left corner of the screen. Later in the game, you can earn up to 6 light bulbs. If all of the light bulbs burn out, a cutscene will play when the last light bulb goes out then the Rabbid yells BWAAAH! then the Rabbids will get set back to an automated checkpoint, and if all of the stuff they have collected is lost, they'll reappear next to the most recent Collector Rabbid they've met. The player can move the shopping cart with the Nunchuk attachment and accelerate using the A button. The Rabbids' main mode of offense is a loud vocalization called the "Bwaaaah! Attack", which can be triggered by shaking the Wii Remote. This attack can break certain objects, stun enemies like guard dogs, scaring humans and stripping them of their clothing. As the player advances through the game, the Verminators and robots appear and humans will start wearing soundproof helmets to protect themselves from the "Bwaaaah! Attack". The player can perform another technique named the "Super Boost", which is initiated when the shopping cart turns and drifts to the point where blue sparks fly from under the cart's wheels. When the player presses the A button and turn, and when blue sparks are coming from the wheels, and presses the B button, the "Super Boost" will be performed. This ability allows the player to knock down piles of crates, strip certain enemies faster and leap over obstacles through the use of springboards. The player can also launch the "Cannonball Rabbid", a Rabbid living inside the player's Wii Remote, by aiming with the Wii Remote and pressing the Z button on the Nunchuk attachment. This attack can strip certain enemies and open certain grates marked with "Tag".{{cite book |title=Rabbids Go Home instruction booklet |year=2009 |publisher=Ubisoft |page=5 |accessdate=December 29, 2009}} At several points during the game, a rabbid is "drawn" into the Wii Remote itself, and can be thrown and bounced around while "inside" the remote as the screen displays an apparent interior view of the remote. ==Plot== After invading Earth and partying intensely, the Rabbids are ready to get back home. Due to having the attention span of a [[goldfish]], they decide to go to the moon, which they think is a giant [[light bulb]]. They come up with a plan to collect all of the human stuff they can find, heap it onto a giant pile and climb to the Moon. They gather the human objects and fit them all into one shopping cart, transfer all of the stuff they have found through the sewage system via a series of toilets and add the stuff to their growing pile, which becomes higher as the game progresses. Eventually, the humans revolt against the Rabbids and become "Verminators" in a bid to exterminate the Rabbids and retrieve their stolen stuff.{{cite book |title=Rabbids Go Home instruction booklet |year=2009 |publisher=Ubisoft |page=3 |accessdate=December 29, 2009}} At the end of the game, the Rabbids are still not able to reach the moon, even after gathering almost everything from the city. The humans bombard the pile with time-delay bombs which explode on the pile, causing the pile to fly up into space. At the result of that, the XL junk falls from the sky and the humans panic. After all of the stuff has stopped falling, the humans are over-joyed to have all of their stuff back. In space, the Rabbids celebrate their accomplishment of finally reaching the moon, albeit caught in the moon's gravitational orbit. ==Development== ''Rabbids Go Home'' underwent three years of development before its release. A coherent and authentic storyline was needed to keep the Rabbids fresh and conserve their variety in the context of an adventure game. The development team evaluated the Rabbids as representing "emotions pushed to the extreme" and created the human characters to be the exact opposite: "[They] mull over all their decisions, their emotions in-check. Their organs have atrophied. They have nearly forgotten that they have a body or a heart, and can barely handle those." Jacques Exertier stated that the meeting between the two opposing characters is an allegory of the "internal debates we have with ourselves each time we make a decision" and that much of the comedic situations in the game stem from the meeting of the two archetypes. The setting of ''Rabbids Go Home'' was visually inspired by the period between 1945 and 1975, during which there was an explosion in mass consumption. The visuals were based on simple colors and geometric shapes rather than photorealism to create a caricaturized image of its "uptight humans with their sterile places and normalized urban planning". ''Rabbids Go Home'' is the first video game to feature the [[LyN]], which was created alongside the game. The game was announced on April 9, 2009.{{cite web |url=http://wii.ign.com/articles/971/971455p1.html |title=Ubisoft Announces ''Rabbids Go Home'' - Wii story - at IGN |author=IGN Staff |date=April 9, 2009 |publisher=IGN |accessdate=April 9, 2009}} On November 17, 2009, Ubisoft denied a rumor that the game would be recalled from United Kingdom shops due to "inappropriate language".{{cite web |url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=227488 |title=Wii News: Ubisoft deny ''Rabbids'' recall rumour - ComputerAndVideoGames.com |author=Stephen Daultrey |date=November 17, 2009 |publisher=ComputerAndVideoGames.com |accessdate=December 29, 2009}} As a result of this, the game has been re-rated a 12 in Europe. {{citation needed|date=December 2011}} ==Music== The music of ''Rabbids Go Home'' was composed by Fanfare Vagabontu, a [[Moldovans|Moldovan]] [[Romani people|gypsy]] [[brass band]], but inspired from the Romanian folk music. A 12-track soundtrack was made available on the [[iTunes Store#Music|iTunes Music Store]] on November 17, 2009.{{cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/raving-rabbids-rabbids-go-home/id341205344 |title=''Raving Rabbids: Rabbids Go Home'' (Original Soundtrack) |author=Fanfare Vagabontu |date=November 17, 2009 |work= |publisher=iTunes |accessdate=December 29, 2009}} The game also includes licensed songs such as "[[Come Go With Me]]" by [[The Del-Vikings]], "[[Louie Louie]]" by [[Richard Berry (musician)|Richard Berry]], "[[Take Me Home, Country Roads]]" by [[John Denver]],{{cite web |url=http://www.nintendoworldreport.com/reviewArt.cfm?artid=20327 |title=Nintendo World Report - Wii Review: ''Rabbids Go Home'' |author=Pedro Hernandez |date=November 16, 2009 |publisher=Nintendo World Report |accessdate=December 29, 2009}} "[[Jamaica Farewell]]" by [[Harry Belafonte]], "[[Somebody to Love (Jefferson Airplane song)|Somebody to Love]]" by [[Jefferson Airplane]], "[[I Told You So (The Delfonics song)|I Told You So]]" by [[The Delfonics]], "[[Smarty Pants]]" by [[First Choice (band)|First Choice]], "[[Me and Mrs. Jones]]" by [[Billy Paul]]{{cite web |url=http://www.1up.com/do/reviewPage?cId=3176873&p=44 |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' Review for the Wii from 1UP.com |author=Matt Leone |date=November 11, 2009 |publisher=1UP.com |accessdate=December 30, 2009}} and "[[Rivers of Babylon]]" by [[Boney M]]. The licensed music is primarily heard coming from radios and loudspeakers in various areas of the game and can be shut off (or quieted down) by destroying said loudspeakers and radios. {{tracklist | collapsed = yes | headline = ''Raving Rabbids: Rabbids Go Home'' (Original Soundtrack) | total_length = 22:54 | title1 = Sanie Cu Zurgălăi | length1 = 2:33 | title2 = Perinita | length2 = 1:22 | title3 = Ciocarlia | length3 = 2:44 | title4 = Bãtutã Din Moldova | length4 = 1:15 | title5 = Doinã Deascultare | length5 = 3:01 | title6 = Bãtutã la Clarinet | length6 = 1:24 | title7 = Bubamara | length7 = 2:52 | title8 = Horã Moldoveneasca de Joc | length8 = 1:28 | title9 = Cântare Din Banat | length9 = 1:18 | title10 = Batutã la Trompeta | length10 = 1:02 | title11 = Horã de Joc | length11 = 1:21 | title12 = Sanie Cu Zurgălăi (DJ Forzando Remix) | length12 = 2:34 }} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | DS = true | WII = true | 1UP_WII = B | EuroG_WII = 8/10 | GI_WII = 7.5/10 | GamePro_WII = 4/5 | GMaster_WII = 86% | GSpot_WII = 7/10 | GameZone_WII = 8/10 | IGN_WII = 8.5/10 | NP_DS = 7/10 | NP_WII = 7/10 | NWR_WII = 9/10 | ONM_DS = 40% | ONM_WII = 83% | GR_DS = 68.25%{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ds/960252-rabbids-go-home/index.html |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' for DS - GameRankings |publisher=GameRankings |accessdate=December 29, 2009}} | GR_WII = 80.25%{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/wii/959321-rabbids-go-home/index.html |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' for Wii - GameRankings |publisher=GameRankings |accessdate=December 29, 2009}} | MC_DS = 70%{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/ds/rabbidsgohome |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' (ds) reviews at Metacritic.com |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=December 29, 2009}} | MC_WII = 79%{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/wii/rabbidsgohome |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' (wii) reviews at Metacritic.com |publisher=Metacritic |accessdate=December 26, 2009}} }} The Wii version of ''Rabbids Go Home'' received generally favorable reviews from critics. Pedro Hernandez of ''[[Nintendo World Report]]'' praised the game's "inventive" uses for the Wii Remote, "easy-to-get-into" gameplay, "deep" Rabbid customization modes, "great" soundtrack and "incredible" sense of humor, but noted the redundancy of the gameplay and inconsistent framerate as weak points. ''[[NGamer]] UK'' concluded that "the Rabbids can pull off a fully fledged game without Rayman's assistance. This is witty, charming and, above all, incredible fun."{{cite web |url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=226656 |title=Wii Review: ''Rabbids Go Home'' Review - ComputerAndVideoGames.com |author=NGamer Staff |date=November 4, 2009 |publisher=NGamer UK |accessdate=December 29, 2009 |quote=The Rabbids can pull off a fully fledged game without Rayman's assistance. This is witty, charming and, above all, incredible fun."}} ''[[GamesMaster]] UK'' described the game as "witty, energetic and hugely entertaining, even if it isn't particularly smart."{{cite journal |year=2009 |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' |journal=GamesMaster UK |issue=Winter 2009 |pages=72 |quote=Witty, energetic and hugely entertaining, even if it isn't particularly smart.}} Matt Casamassina of [[IGN]] stated that the game was "far more inspired and ambitious" than ''[[Rayman Raving Rabbids]]'' and said that the title "at times feels like an action romp and at times a platformer on wheels, but regardless of the scenario, you'll be having fun and smiling if not laughing."{{cite web |url=http://wii.ign.com/articles/104/1041704p1.html |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' Review - Wii Review - at IGN |author=Matt Casamassina |date=November 3, 2009 |publisher= [[News Corporation]] | work = [[IGN]] |accessdate=December 29, 2009 |quote=''Rabbids Go Home'' is not a ''Raving Rabbids'' sequel, but an altogether different experience -- one far more inspired and ambitious. This title at times feels like an action romp and at times a platformer on wheels, but regardless of the scenario, you'll be having fun and smiling if not laughing.}} Chris Scullion of ''[[Official Nintendo Magazine]] UK'' considered ''Rabbids Go Home'' to be "the funniest game on the Wii" and commented positively on the "tight" controls and "fantastic" soundtrack, but stated that the game was too easy.{{cite web |url=http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/article.php?id=12973 |title=Review: ''Rabbids Go Home'' - Official Nintendo Magazine |author=Chris Scullion |date=November 4, 2009 |publisher=Official Nintendo Magazine UK |accessdate=December 29, 2009 |quote=It's an absolute hoot but if you're after a meaty challenge, you definitely won't find it here.}} Aceinet of GameZone praised the game's humor and "ever-changing" gameplay, concluding with a reminder that "games are supposed to be fun and ''Rabbids Go Home'' is a fun-filled experience that shouldn’t be missed regardless of the score."{{cite web |url=http://wii.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r37888.htm |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' Review - Wii |author=Aceinet |date=November 16, 2009 |publisher=GameZone |accessdate=December 29, 2009 |quote=The humor and ever changing gameplay provides a rip-roaring experience that you’ll be hard pressed to find in another game. Remember games are supposed to be fun and ''Rabbids Go Home'' is a fun-filled experience that shouldn’t be missed regardless of the score.}} Aaron Koehn of [[GamePro]] pointed out that the game draws its strength from its odd tone, but added that the simplicity of the gameplay becomes tiresome.{{cite web |url=http://www.gamepro.com/article/reviews/212967/rabbids-go-home/ |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' Review from GamePro |author=Aaron Koehn |date=November 16, 2009 |publisher=GamePro |accessdate=December 30, 2009 |quote=Even with the game's strength is its unusual and original tone, players can rest assured that this game is just as accessible as it is odd. Featuring an overdose of quirky charm and a wide range of fun-filled gameplay, gamers who aren't used to playing titles outside of the norm will be remiss if they don't give ''Rabbids Go Home'' a chance.|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091121112433/http://www.gamepro.com/article/reviews/212967/rabbids-go-home/|archivedate=2009-11-21}} Dan Pearson of [[Eurogamer]] noted that the "constant enthusiasm" of the Rabbids can be "draining" to some and said that the game wasn't for hardcore gaming enthusiasts.{{cite web |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/rabbids-go-home-review |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' Review | Wii | Eurogamer |author=Dan Pearson |date=November 9, 2009 |publisher=EuroGamer |accessdate=December 30, 2009 |quote=Not everyone is going to enjoy this. Some people will never warm to Ubisoft's anarchic little fiends, many will find the constant enthusiasm draining. This isn't a purchase for hardcore enthusiasts or steely battlefield veterans with a thousand-yard stare and a pico-second response time. The rest of you, should you be able to engage your inner child, could well find a big old slice of the fun pie cooling on your windowsill.}} Annette Gonzalez of ''[[Game Informer]]'' said that the animations were "laugh-out-loud", but some of the gameplay sequences were "repetitive".{{cite web |url=http://gameinformer.com/games/rabbids_go_home/b/wii/archive/2009/11/03/review.aspx |title=Rabbids Ditch Minigames For A Fun Item-collecting Adventure - ''Rabbids Go Home'' - Nintendo Wii |author=Annette Gonzalez |date=November 3, 2009 |publisher=Game Informer |accessdate=December 30, 2009}} Matt Leone of [[1UP.com]] remarked that the licensed soundtrack and customization features added enough personality to make the game worth playing. ''[[Nintendo Power]]'' concluded that while the game was too easy, it was "a definite step in the right direction for the Rabbids, and I hope to see them continue this way."{{cite journal |year=2009 |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' |journal=Nintendo Power |issue=Holiday 2009 |pages=88 |quote=Difficulty issues aside, this is a definite step in the right direction for the Rabbids, and I hope to see them continue this way.}} Tom McShea of [[GameSpot]] commented positively on the character creator, unlockable content and cutscenes, but said that the early levels were too easy and simple and the game became repetitive.{{cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/wii/adventure/rabbidsgohome/review.html |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' Review for Wii - GameSpot |author=Tom McShea |date=November 10, 2009 |publisher=GameSpot |accessdate=December 30, 2009 |quote=This slow-starting platformer is simple at times but builds up to a goofy good time.}} Reviews for the Nintendo DS version were mixed. ''NGamer UK'' called the game "the best example of the genre we've seen in ages."{{cite journal |year=2009 |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' |journal=NGamer UK |issue=Christmas 2009 |pages=70 |quote=The best example of the genre we've seen in ages.}} ''Nintendo Power'' said that the game's style of puzzle is "perfect" for touch-screen control and noted that the ability to customize challenges "adds a lot of replay value to this latest exercise in Rabbid abuse."{{cite journal |year=2009 |title=''Rabbids Go Home'' |journal=Nintendo Power |issue=Holiday 2009 |pages=89 |quote=It's the perfect style of puzzle for touch-screen controls, and there's an edit mode for designing your own custom challenges, which adds a lot of replay value to this latest exercise in Rabbid abuse.}} Chris Scullion of ''Official Nintendo Magazine UK'' criticized the game's "broken" physics, "universally dull" minigames and "irritating" gameplay, but noted that the cutscenes were "decent" and the level editor is "solid".{{cite web |url=http://www.officialnintendomagazine.co.uk/article.php?id=14047 |title=Nintendo Review: ''Rabbids Go Home'' - Official Nintendo Magazine |author=Chris Scullion |date=December 17, 2009 |publisher=Official Nintendo Magazine UK |accessdate=December 29, 2009 |quote=Never have we seen a DS game fail so badly to capture the fun of its Wii sibling.}} ==References== {{Reflist|35em}} {{Raving Rabbids series}} {{Ubisoft Montpellier}} {{LyN games}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:2009 video games]] [[Category:Action-adventure games]] [[Category:LyN games]] [[Category:Raving Rabbids]] [[Category:Nintendo DS games]] [[Category:Ubisoft games]] [[Category:Video game sequels]] [[Category:Video games developed in France]] [[Category:Video games set in 2008]] [[Category:Wii games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Japan]] [[Category:Video games developed in China]] [[Category:Video games developed in South Korea]] [[Category:Video games developed in Thailand]] [[Category:Video games developed in Vietnam]] [[Category:Video games developed in Taiwan]] [[Category:Video games developed in Russia]]
