revision.comment: /* Female rappers as video vixens */Removed Angel Haze. She is a queer rapper who does not pander to the male gaze.
revision.text:
{{for|the movie|Video Vixens}} {{Essay-like|date=November 2015}} [[File:NickiMinaj7109.jpg|thumb|250px|The performer [[Nicki Minaj]] in concert. Minaj has been described as a video vixen.<ref name="genius.it">{{cite web|author=Aun Qi Koh|title='It's Barbie, bitch!': In Defense of Nicki Minaj, Black Female Rappers and Hip-hop Feminism|url=http://genius.it/politicalbeanie.tumblr.com/post/30586122228/its-barbie-bitch-in-defense-of-nicki-minaj|publisher=Political Beanie|date=September 1, 2012}}</ref>]] A '''video vixen''' (also '''hip hop honey''' or '''video girl'''<ref>{{cite book|last=Shalit|first=Wendy|authorlink=Wendy Shalit|title=[[Girls Gone Mild|Girls Gone Mild: Young Women Reclaim Self-Respect and Find It's Not Bad to Be Good]]|year =2007|publisher =Random House|location=New York|isbn= 978-1-4000-6473-1|page= 72| quote = [...] girls of color have a whole aspect of hip-hop with those horrible videos and the rise of the hip-hop honey or video girl.}}</ref>) is a female [[model (person)|model]] who appears in [[hip-hop]]-oriented [[music video]]s. The video vixen image has become a staple and a nuanced form of sex work within popular music; especially within the genre of hip-hop.<ref name="auto">Story, Kaila A. "Performing Venus-From Hottentot to Video Vixen." Home Girls Make Some Noise: Hip-hop Feminism Anthology. By Gwendolyn D. Pough, Mark Anthony. Neal, and Joan Morgan. Mira Loma, CA: Parker Pub., 2007. N. pag. Print.</ref> Many video vixens are aspiring actors, singers, dancers, or professional models.<ref>Sharpley-Whiting, T. Denean. [https://books.google.com/books?id=1Q7EvbA2wIoC&pg=PA26 ''Pimps up, Ho's down: Hip Hop's Hold on Young Black Women'']. New York: New York University Press, 2007, p. 26, {{ISBN|978-0-8147-4014-9}}.</ref> Women from various cultures have been portrayed either as fragile, manipulative, fetishistic, or submissive within contemporary music lyrics, videos, concert and movie soundtracks,<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|url = |title = What It Do, Shorty?: Women, Hip-Hop, and a Feminist Agenda|last = Pough|first = Gwendolyn|date = 2007|journal = Black Women, Gender + Families|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> although this is not universal, as demonstrated by the archetypal [[ride-or-die chick]].
==Stereotyping== Biblical imagery accompanied by [[chauvinism]] morphs black female performers into "The Black Jezebel". This caricature portrays black women as promiscuous, unintelligent, and deceptive. This comes from biblical implications that [[Jezebel]]'s "beauty" captivated [[King Ahab]], in such a way, that it drove him from reason and he turned from God, to instead worship idols because he was blinded by his lust for her. Black women under this type of social gaze are not seen as valuable. The only value given to them is derived from their physique highlighted by form fitting clothing that exaggerates the female form. There is continued [[hypersexualisation]] of the video vixen.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Harris|first=Tamara|date=March 15, 2016|title=Sunday Kind of Love: Sex and Spirituality in the Black Church|url=|journal=Bitch Magazine|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Social aspect==
The work of video vixens and their portrayal in music videos have drawn criticism. Critics suggest that music-video models are typically placed in [[subordinate]] and [[submissive]] roles while male artists are shown in positions of power.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Conrad | first1 = Kate | last2 = Dixon | first2 = Travis | last3 = Zhang | first3 = Yuanyuan | year = 2009 | title = Controversial Rap Themes, Gender Portrayals and Skin Tone Distortion: A Content Analysis of Rap Music Videos | url = | journal = Journal of Broadcasting & Electronic Media | volume = 53 | issue = 1| pages = 134–156 | doi = 10.1080/08838150802643795 }}</ref><ref name="encyclopedia of women">Stange, Mary Zeiss; Carol K. Oyster; Jane Sloan. [https://books.google.com/books?id=B50Jad7552MC&pg=PA695 ''Encyclopedia of Women in Today's World'']. Thousand Oaks, Calif.: Sage Reference, 2011, p. 695, {{ISBN|978-1-4129-7685-5}}.</ref> Others argue that music-video models are depicted as [[sexual objectification|sexual objects]], signs of male power, and referred to in derogatory terms such as "[[Bitch (insult)|bitch]]" and "[[slut]]".<ref>Hall, Ann C.; Mardia J. Bishop. [https://books.google.com/books?id=xKbsYHyShI8C&pg=PA8 ''Pop-Porn: Pornography in American Culture'']. Westport, Conn.: Praeger, 2007, p. 8, {{ISBN|978-0-275-99920-9}}.</ref><ref>Jeffries, Michael P. [https://books.google.com/books?id=a3bIlG3lrswC&pg=PA155 ''Thug Life: Race, Gender, and the Meaning of Hip-Hop'']. Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 2011, p. 155, {{ISBN|978-0-226-39584-5}}.</ref><ref>Keyes, Cheryl Lynette. [https://books.google.com/books?id=HRmRqtD6oPgC&pg=PA220 ''Rap Music and Street Consciousness'']. Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 2002, p. 220, {{ISBN|978-0-252-02761-1}}.</ref>
In 2004, [[Nelly]]'s video for his song "[[Tip Drill (song)|Tip Drill]]" came under particular criticism for its depiction and sexual objectification of women.<ref name="Nelly">Bailey, Moya (May 24, 2004). [http://alternet.org/story/18760/ "Students at Spelman College protest Nelly's video 'Tip Drill.'"] ''Alternet.org.'' Retrieved on February 11, 2006.</ref><ref>[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2004-04-02/news/0404030019_1_spelman-college-bone-marrow-nelly "Nelly feels the heat"]. ''[[The Chicago Tribune]]'' (April 02, 2005), accessed October 01, 2011.</ref><ref>Arce, Rose (March 04, 2005). [http://articles.cnn.com/2005-03-03/entertainment/hip.hop_1_hip-hop-black-women-spelman-college/2?_s=PM:SHOWBIZ "Hip-hop portrayal of women protested"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120405053730/http://articles.cnn.com/2005-03-03/entertainment/hip.hop_1_hip-hop-black-women-spelman-college/2?_s=PM:SHOWBIZ |date=April 5, 2012 }}. [[CNN]], accessed October 01, 2011.</ref> While some people pointed out that the women who appeared in Nelly's video voluntarily chose to participate,<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2004-04-23-spelman-protest-rappers_x.htm "Black college women take aim at rappers"]. ''[[USAToday]]'' (April 23, 2004), accessed October 01, 2011.</ref> others insisted that male rappers continue to sexually objectify hip hop models<ref name="encyclopedia of women"/> while denying that the hip hop artists' career is, at least in part, based on the exploitation of other people.<ref>Rose, Tricia. [https://www.scribd.com/doc/59800963/The-Hip-Hop-Wars-What-We-Talk-About-When-We-Talk-About-Hip-Hop-And-Why-It-Matters ''The Hip Hop Wars: What We Talk About When We Talk About Hip Hop - And Why It Matters'']. New York: BasicCivitas, 2008, p. 177, {{ISBN|978-0-465-00897-1}}.</ref>
In 2005, former hip hop music-video model [[Karrine Steffans]] authored the book ''[[Confessions of a Video Vixen]]'', in which she depicts the degradation of women in the world of hip hop. The book's publisher describes it as "part tell-all, part cautionary tale".<ref name="VVbook">[http://www.harpercollins.com/global_scripts/product_catalog/book_xml.asp?isbn=0060842423 "''Confessions of a Video Vixen'' by Karrine Steffans"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051212141513/http://www.harpercollins.com/global_scripts/product_catalog/book_xml.asp?isbn=0060842423 |date=December 12, 2005 }}. ''HarperCollins.com''. Retrieved on February 11, 2006.</ref> The book went on to be a best seller in the US.<ref name="NYT Confessions">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/24/books/bestseller/0724besthardnonfiction.html |title=Best Sellers: Hardcover Nonfiction |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=July 24, 2005}}</ref> Another hip hop model, Candace Smith, said in an ''XXL'' interview, "what I've seen on [hip hop music video] sets is complete degradation".<ref name="CSmith">Salaam, Khalid and Palting, Joaquin (2006). [http://xxlmag.com/EyeCandy/2006/ec.candice/index.html "Eye Candy: Tastes Like Candace"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060117101954/http://xxlmag.com/EyeCandy/2006/ec.candice/index.html |date=January 17, 2006 }}. ''XXL Magazine''. New York: Harris Publications. Retrieved on February 11, 2006.</ref>
==Female rappers as video vixens== Female rappers have most substantially felt this pressure, where sex appeal is now the currency by which women in the music business are valued and devalued. In particular, female rappers such as [[Lil' Kim]] and [[Trina]] occupy what T. Denean Sharpley-Whiting calls a "peculiar place of cultural antipathy", often accused of selling out and blamed for participating in the exploitation of women.<ref name="genius.it"/> Similarly, [[Nicki Minaj]] is arguably a 'video vixen' who is the 'object, subject, and author' of sexually explicit music videos.<ref name="genius.it"/>
Female rappers who have shown themselves off as "video vixens" include [[Nicki Minaj]], [[Trina (rapper)|Trina]], [[Eve (rapper)|Eve]], [[Rasheeda]], [[Foxy Brown (rapper)|Foxy Brown]], [[Remy Ma]], [[Da Brat]], [[Jacki-O]], [[Shawnna]], [[Gangsta Boo]], [[LoLa Monroe]], [[Diamond (rapper)|Diamond]] [[Princess (rapper)|Princess]], and Cardi B. The role women have evolved over time in the hip-hop world. Rapper Roxane Shante and Salt-N-Pepa were at the beginning where they were rapping about defending women's image.<ref name=":0" /> They were responding to male hip-hop artists for degrading women.<ref name=":0" /> Rappers Lil Kim, Foxy Brown, Trina, Nicki Minaj and many others are all opposite in accepting hyper-sexuality.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Women, Pop Music, and Pornography|last = Levande|first = Meredith|date = 2008|journal = Meridians|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref>
== Black women in hip hop == [[Audre Lorde]], who spoke out for black girls who are considered video vixens (although she herself was never a video vixen or closely associated with hip hop), said: "If I didn't define myself for myself, I would be crunched into other people's fantasies for me and eaten alive."<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Vixen Resistin': Redefining Black Womanhood in Hip Hop Music Videos|last = Balaji|first = Murali|date = 2010|journal = Journal of Black Studies|doi = 10.1177/0021934708325377 }}</ref> The images presented in mass media, specifically in music videos, portray hyper-sensual images of the female sex. These images created within the world of hip hop reinforce the negative stereotypes associated especially with the black female.
It is pressuring for women musicians to conform to the porn standards because if not they will have to compete with the women who do.<ref name=":2" />
People realize that images of women is what rap music videos sell whether the women in the videos are playing the part of cheerleaders or die-hard groupies. Women in the videos are what gets the attention of men and guarantee males audiences.<ref name=":2" /> The images are still shots of women taken from videos displaying their appearance. Women are tended to dress half naked and moving their body in sexual ways.<ref name=":2" /> Media have given a clear definition that African American women are only seen as sexual figures in the society. Once these images are put out there these women are not the owner of their representation anymore.<ref name=":1" />
== Expressing femininity in hip hop == Gender Performance is an evolving category where hip hop artists express femininity in nonconventional ways that break the stereotype of the passive, hyper-sexualized female body as an object to be consumed.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Johnson|first=Imani Kai|date=April 12, 2014|title=From blues women to b-girls: performing badass femininity|url=https://bbnewpaltz.sln.suny.edu/bbcswebdav/pid-1861563-dt-content-rid-2699459_2/courses/spring16_WOM393_02/Johnson_Badass%20Femininity.pdf|journal=Women & Performance: a journal of feminist theory|doi=|pmid=|access-date=March 6, 2016}}</ref> Throughout the genre in graffiti, breakdancing, and rapping, women are addressing the issues associated with the passive stereotype of female representation in hip hop. [[Feminist activism in hip hop]] re-examines the relationship women have to the hip hop culture, and how women choose to assert their sexuality.
A form of femininity in hip hop is through asserting sexuality and using it as a dominant source of power, creating the notion of being liberated and a subject as opposed to an object.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=Home Girls Make Some Noise: Hip Hop Feminism Anthology|last=Pough|first=Gwendolyn D.|publisher=Parker Publishing|year=2007|isbn=978-1-60043-010-7|location=Mira Loma, California|pages=116–127}}</ref> Artists within this category use blatant sexuality to their advantage as a part of their marketing and work, by using sexuality to their advantage. Due to the commodification of hip hop and stereotyping, the "sex sells" concept became prominent within mainstream hip hop culture.
==Successful career paths== Some video vixens who have made a name for themselves in the music video industry, as well as girls with limited work as hip hop models, have gone on to other types of work with greater success, mostly by marketing themselves.
[[Nicole Alexander]] became an American reality TV show contestant and is known for winning the [[VH1]] reality television shows of ''[[Flavor of Love]]'' in its [[Flavor of Love (season 1)|first season]] and ''[[I Love Money (season 1)|I Love Money]]''.<ref name="reality blurred">{{cite web|url=http://www.realityblurred.com/realitytv/archives/i_love_money/2008_Oct_07_hoopz_wins|title=Hoopz wins I Love Money|author=Andy Dehnart|work=reality blurred|accessdate=9 May 2015}}</ref> Another reality show winner was [[Chandra Davis]] who won the second season of [[VH1|VH1's]] [[Flavor of Love]] competition.
[[Leila Arcieri]] was voted Miss San Francisco in the 1997 [[Miss California]] pageant and went on to act in television series, such as ''[[Son of the Beach]]'', a parody of ''[[Baywatch]]''. [[Melyssa Ford]] is an on-air personality for [[Sirius Satellite Radio]]'s [[Hot Jamz]] channel.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sirius.com/servlet/ContentServer?pagename=Sirius/CachedPage&c=Channel&cid=1104779639899&flash=noflash |title=Hot Jamz |accessdate=January 25, 2009 |publisher=Sirius Satellite Radio |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120909082843/http://www.sirius.com/servlet/ContentServer?pagename=Sirius/CachedPage&c=Channel&cid=1104779639899&flash=noflash |archivedate=October 14, 2008 |quote=Hot Jamz is about to get a lot hotter: Melyssa Ford has joined our squad! }}</ref>
[[Vida Guerra]] has modelled for many magazines, including ''[[DUB Magazine|DUB]]'', ''[[Smooth (magazine)|Smooth]]'', ''[[Escape (magazine)|Escape]]'', and ''[[Open Your Eyes (magazine)|Open Your Eyes]]'', often as the [[cover girl]]. She has also made multiple appearances on several [[Spanish language]] [[television program]]s, such as entertainment gossip show ''[[El Gordo y la Flaca]]'', and [[Television advertisement|commercials]] for [[Burger King]]'s [[TenderCrisp|TenderCrisp Bacon Cheddar Ranch]]. She's lent her voice to the video game ''[[Scarface: The World Is Yours]]''. [[Lauren London]] has a successful [[Lauren London#Career|career]] in movies and television. [[Angel Melaku]], [[Nicole Narain]] went on to acting careers, while [[LisaRaye McCoy]] became a famous actress.
[[Buffie Carruth]] appeared in the movie ''[[ATL (film)|ATL]]'', made a fitness-instruction DVD,<ref>Grade A Glutes by Buffie the Body (2013)". Amazon.com. August 17, 2013. Retrieved December 1, 2013</ref> and has a written a book about her life.<ref>Carruth, Buffie. (2009). "Vixen Icon". Triple Crown Publications. 978-0091874759</ref>
==See also== *[[Misogyny in hip hop culture]] *[[Sexuality in music videos]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *Thompson, Bonsu and Huang, Howard (August 4, 2004). [https://web.archive.org/web/20060117060429/http://www.xxlmag.com/EyeCandy/2004/0804.hall-of-fame/index.html "Eye Candy Hall of Fame"]. ''XXL Magazine''. New York: Harris Publications. Retrieved on February 11, 2006.
{{African American caricatures and stereotypes}}Amazing Aura. n.d. ''Black Women in Sex Work (How and Why Colorism and Racism Exists in Strip Clubs and Sex Work)''. Accessed March 5, 2018. <nowiki>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nRq-0yLAx28</nowiki>. [[Category:Modeling]] [[Category:History of hip hop]] [[Category:African-American gender relations]]

revision.comment: migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Wilfried Schmickler|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=July 2013}}
[[Image:2007-11-11 Wilfried Schmickler, Pantheon, Bonn IMG 1830.jpg|thumb|right|Wilfried Schmickler in Pantheon, Bonn, 2007]] '''Wilfried Schmickler''' (born 28 November 1954 in [[Hitdorf]], [[Leverkusen]]) is a [[Germany|German]] [[comedian]] and cabaret artist.
== Life == Schmickler works as a comedian in Germany on TV-shows, in radio and on theatre stages. His programme consist of political [[cabaret]].
== Solo programmes by Schmickler ==
* ''Aufhören!'' (2004) * ''Danke!'' (2005) * ''Zum Dritten'' (2007) * ''Es war nicht alles schlecht'' (2009) * ''Weiter'' (2010) * ''Ich weiss es doch auch nicht'' (2012)
== Awards ==
* 2001 – Deutscher Kleinkunstpreis together with ''3-Gestirn'' * 2007 – Prix Pantheon, special award ''Reif & Bekloppt'' * 2007 – Deutscher Kabarettpreis * 2009 – Deutscher Kleinkunstpreis, Sparte Kabarett * 2010 – ''Salzburger Stier''
== External links == * {{DNB-Portal|114857725}} *[http://www.wilfriedschmickler.de Website by Wilfried Schmickler] *[http://www.koeln-magazin.info/wilfriedschmickler.html Portrait and Audiopodcast] at koeln-magazin.info *[http://www.wdr2.de/unterhaltung/kabarett/wilfried_schmickler100.html Wilfried Schmicklers Hörfunkglosse at WDR 2]
== References == <references />
{{Authority control}}
